domains.name: Gross Motor Development
domains.description: Gross motor skills involve large muscle movements like walking, running, jumping, and climbing. These skills are essential for physical independence, participation in sports and play, and overall health. Strong gross motor development supports balance, coordination, and body awareness, which are foundational for more complex physical activities and daily tasks.

tier1.question: Does your child walk alone without help?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Independent walking is a major milestone usually achieved by 18 months.

tier1.question: Can your child walk up stairs holding your hand or a rail?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Stair negotiation shows leg strength and balance.

tier1.question: Does your child kick a ball without falling?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Kicking requires standing on one leg momentarily.

tier1.question: Can your child run (or trot) without frequent falling?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Running indicates coordination and motor planning.

tier1.question: Does your child squat to pick up toys and stand back up without falling?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Squatting and rising demonstrates leg strength and balance control.

tier2.question: Can your child jump in place with both feet leaving the ground?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Jumping shows explosive leg power and coordination.

tier2.question: Does your child walk backward for a few steps?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Walking backward requires advanced spatial awareness and motor control.

tier2.question: Can your child carry a large toy while walking?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Carrying objects while moving shows refined balance and coordination.

tier2.question: Does your child pull or push toys while walking?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Managing toys while moving indicates advanced motor planning.

tier2.question: Does your child throw a ball overhand?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Overhand throwing requires shoulder control and visual-motor coordination.

domains.name: Fine Motor & Visual-Motor
domains.description: Fine motor skills involve precise movements of small muscles in the hands and fingers. These skills are crucial for self-care tasks (buttoning, zipping), academic activities (writing, cutting), and creative expression (drawing, building). Visual-motor integration combines what the eyes see with hand movements, essential for handwriting and many daily activities.

tier1.question: Does your child stack 4 or more blocks/objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Stacking requires precision and hand-eye coordination.

tier1.question: Can your child scribble spontaneously?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Scribbling is the precursor to writing and drawing.

tier1.question: Does your child turn pages of a book (one or a few at a time)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Page turning refines finger dexterity.

tier1.question: Can your child dump a small object out of a bottle?
tier1.whyWeAsk: This combines fine motor skill with cognitive understanding.

tier1.question: Does your child use a pincer grasp to pick up small objects between thumb and finger?
tier1.whyWeAsk: The pincer grasp is essential for self-feeding and later writing skills.

tier2.question: Does your child try to copy a vertical line?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Copying shapes shows visual perception and motor control.

tier2.question: Can your child string large beads onto a shoelace or string?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Stringing beads requires using both hands together in a coordinated way.

tier2.question: Does your child hold a crayon with fingers rather than a fist?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Refined crayon grip indicates developing hand control for writing.

tier2.question: Can your child build a tower of 6 or more blocks?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Higher towers require increased precision and motor control.

tier2.question: Does your child attempt to unscrew lids from containers?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Unscrewing requires complex wrist rotation and bilateral hand coordination.

domains.name: Speech & Language
domains.description: Speech and language development encompasses both the ability to produce clear sounds (speech) and to understand and use words meaningfully (language). Strong communication skills are fundamental for expressing needs, building relationships, learning in school, and participating fully in social situations. Delays in this area can impact all aspects of development.

tier1.question: Does your child use at least 15-20 words consistently?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Limited vocabulary can indicate language delay.

tier1.question: Does your child join two words together (e.g., 'more juice', 'mama go')?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Two-word phrases mark the beginning of sentence formation.

tier1.question: Does your child point to body parts when asked?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Identifying body parts shows understanding of self and words.

tier1.question: Can your child follow simple one-step commands (e.g., 'Give it to me') without gestures?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Following commands shows comprehension.

tier1.question: Does your child attempt to name pictures in books?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Naming pictures demonstrates vocabulary growth and verbal expression.

tier2.question: Does your child refer to themselves by name?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Using their name indicates self-awareness.

tier2.question: Can your child follow two-step related commands (e.g., 'Get your shoe and bring it here')?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Two-step commands require memory and sequencing of instructions.

tier2.question: Does your child ask simple questions like 'What's that?' or 'Where?'
tier2.whyWeAsk: Asking questions shows curiosity and developing language structure.

tier2.question: Can your child identify familiar objects by sound (e.g., dog barking, phone ringing)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Sound recognition supports language development and listening skills.

tier2.question: Does your child use gestures along with words to communicate needs?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Combining gestures and words shows integrated communication skills.

domains.name: Social & Emotional
domains.description: Social-emotional development includes the ability to understand and manage emotions, form positive relationships, and navigate social situations. These skills are critical for mental health, school readiness, and lifelong success. Children who develop strong social-emotional skills are better equipped to handle stress, resolve conflicts, and build meaningful connections with others.

tier1.question: Does your child copy others, especially adults?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Imitation is a key mechanism for learning social behavior.

tier1.question: Does your child show interest in other children?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Lack of interest in peers can be a red flag for social development.

tier1.question: Does your child play simple pretend games (e.g., feeding a doll)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Pretend play shows cognitive and social maturity.

tier1.question: Does your child cling to caregivers in new situations?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Stranger anxiety is typical but should not prevent all exploration.

tier1.question: Does your child express affection to familiar people (hugs, kisses)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Showing affection indicates healthy attachment and emotional connection.

tier2.question: Does your child have tantrums when frustrated?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Tantrums are typical; total lack of emotion or extreme intensity is noted.

tier2.question: Does your child offer toys or objects to others to share?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Offering objects shows emerging social reciprocity and turn-taking.

tier2.question: Does your child respond when you show excitement or distress?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Responding to others' emotions shows empathy development.

tier2.question: Does your child seek comfort from familiar adults when upset?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Seeking comfort indicates healthy attachment relationships.

tier2.question: Does your child notice when others are hurt or crying?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Noticing others' distress is an early sign of empathy.

domains.name: Cognitive / Learning
domains.description: Cognitive development involves thinking, problem-solving, memory, and understanding concepts. These skills form the foundation for academic learning and everyday decision-making. Strong cognitive abilities help children make sense of their world, learn new information, and apply knowledge in different contexts.

tier1.question: Does your child point to things in a book when you name them?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Connecting words to pictures is a key pre-literacy skill.

tier1.question: Does your child know what ordinary things are for (e.g., telephone, brush, spoon)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Understanding function shows cognitive categorization.

tier1.question: Can your child complete a simple shape sorter (circle into round hole)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Shape sorting involves spatial reasoning.

tier1.question: Does your child search for hidden objects they watched you hide?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Searching for hidden objects shows memory and understanding that objects exist when out of sight.

tier1.question: Does your child sort objects by type (e.g., all spoons together, all blocks together)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Sorting shows early classification and organizational thinking.

tier2.question: Does your child engage in 'parallel play' (playing next to other kids)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Parallel play precedes cooperative play.

tier2.question: Can your child match identical pictures or objects?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Matching demonstrates visual discrimination and comparison skills.

tier2.question: Does your child remember where familiar objects belong in your home?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Remembering object locations shows environmental learning and memory.

tier2.question: Does your child complete simple puzzles with 2-3 large pieces?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Puzzle completion requires spatial understanding and problem-solving.

tier2.question: Can your child imitate actions from memory (e.g., stirring, sweeping)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Imitating remembered actions shows memory and symbolic thinking.

domains.name: Adaptive & Self-Care
domains.description: Adaptive skills are practical life skills needed for independence, including dressing, eating, toileting, and personal hygiene. Mastering these skills builds confidence, reduces dependence on caregivers, and is essential for success in school and community settings. These abilities reflect a child's growing autonomy and self-management.

tier1.question: Does your child use a spoon to eat (some spilling is okay)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Utensil use is a major self-care milestone.

tier1.question: Does your child drink from a cup without a lid?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Cup drinking requires motor control and oral coordination.

tier1.question: Does your child try to help with dressing (e.g., putting on a hat)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Dressing participation encourages independence.

tier1.question: Does your child wash and dry hands with help?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Hand washing shows developing self-care awareness and routines.

tier1.question: Does your child indicate when their diaper is wet or soiled?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Awareness of elimination is a first step toward toilet training readiness.

tier2.question: Does your child unzip a zipper or take off socks intentionally?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Manipulating clothing fasteners is a complex skill.

tier2.question: Can your child put on loose-fitting clothing like a hat or shoes (not necessarily correctly)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Attempting to dress shows growing independence and motor planning.

tier2.question: Does your child try to brush their own teeth (even if not effective)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Attempting tooth brushing shows developing self-care routines.

tier2.question: Can your child use a napkin to wipe their face when prompted?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Wiping face demonstrates emerging cleanliness awareness.

tier2.question: Does your child show interest in using the toilet (wanting to watch, sit on it)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Interest in toileting indicates readiness to begin training.

domains.name: Sensory Processing
domains.description: Sensory processing is how the brain receives and responds to information from the senses (touch, sound, sight, taste, smell, movement, body position). Difficulties in this area can affect attention, behavior, motor skills, and emotional regulation. Understanding a child's sensory needs helps create supportive environments for learning and development.

tier1.question: Does your child enjoy swinging and being tossed in the air?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Avoidance may indicate gravitational insecurity.

tier1.question: Is your child overly bothered by messy hands or face?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Extreme reaction to mess can show tactile defensiveness.

tier1.question: Does your child cover their ears at everyday sounds (vacuum, blender)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Covering ears may indicate auditory hypersensitivity.

tier1.question: Does your child explore new textures (sand, grass, playdough) willingly?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Willingness to explore textures shows appropriate sensory seeking.

tier1.question: Does your child tolerate having hair brushed or nails trimmed?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Extreme distress during grooming may indicate tactile defensiveness.

tier2.question: Does your child seek deep pressure (hugging, squeezing)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Seeking pressure can be a self-regulation strategy.

tier2.question: Does your child seem unaware of bumps or falls that would bother other children?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Under-responsiveness to pain may indicate sensory processing differences.

tier2.question: Does your child become overwhelmed in busy environments (stores, parties)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Overwhelm in busy settings suggests difficulty filtering sensory information.

tier2.question: Does your child mouth or chew on non-food items frequently?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Excessive mouthing may indicate oral sensory seeking or self-regulation needs.

tier2.question: Does your child have difficulty calming down after active play?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Difficulty calming may indicate challenges with sensory regulation.

domains.name: Vision & Hearing
domains.description: Vision and hearing are the primary channels through which children learn about their environment. Clear vision is essential for reading, writing, and visual-motor tasks, while good hearing is critical for language development and communication. Early detection of vision or hearing problems can prevent delays in other developmental areas.

tier1.question: Does your child identify familiar objects in pictures (e.g., 'where is the dog')?
tier1.whyWeAsk: This requires visual recognition and language understanding.

tier1.question: Does your child point to distant objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Seeing and interested in things far away indicates good distance vision.

tier1.question: Does your child turn when you call their name from behind?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Responding to name indicates hearing ability and social awareness.

tier1.question: Does your child watch your face when you talk to them?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Face watching shows visual engagement and social communication.

tier1.question: Does your child respond to quiet sounds like whispers or soft music?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Responding to quiet sounds indicates good hearing acuity.

tier2.question: Does your child tilt their head when looking at things?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Head tilting may compensate for alignment issues.

tier2.question: Does your child frequently rub their eyes or squint?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Eye rubbing or squinting may indicate vision problems or eye strain.

tier2.question: Does your child locate the source of sounds (turn toward a ringing phone or doorbell)?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Sound localization shows spatial hearing and auditory processing.

tier2.question: Does your child seem confused when given spoken directions?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Confusion with directions may indicate hearing or processing difficulties.

tier2.question: Does your child bring objects very close to their face to look at them?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Bringing objects very close may indicate nearsightedness or visual difficulties.
